newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-PEARCE PLEDGES TO STAY AND HELP FOREST WIN PROMOTION.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-PEARCE PLEDGES TO STAY AND HELP FOREST WIN PROMOTION.

text.p: Stuart Pearce pledged his playing future to Nottingham Forest on Thursday after stepping down as caretaker-manager of the relegated premier league club.
"Playing for Forest and England still means everything to me," said the 35-year-old international full-back who failed to prevent Forest from going down during his five months in charge.
As widely expected Pearce handed over control of the team to general manager Dave Bassett who joined the club from Crystal Palace in February.
"I haven't really thought about whether being out of the premier league will affect my international career as a player," said Pearce.

"But the World Cup in France next year is still my big target. That could be my last opportunity to represent my country so I am hoping to still be involved with the England team all the way through to the finals."
Pearce insisted he will have "no problem" giving up the managerial position and reverting to a playing role under his successor.
"I'll give Dave Bassett all the help I can," he said.
"The important thing now is that everyone pulls the same way for him to try and get us promoted next season.
"I've got three years left on my playing contract and I would like to think I'll see them out here.

"If one or two of the players have a problem about me returning to the dressing room my attitude will be the same as when I was manager -- I'm here, I'm doing my job, and they can like it or lump it."
But Pearce admitted it would have been difficult carrying on in charge of the team in a playing and managing capacity.
"When it came to signing new players I didn't have the time to go and watch them first," he said.
"I was having to rely on someone else's judgement when it was my neck on the block. That was one of the hardest parts of the job.
"But I enjoyed the experience and would like to go back into management at the end of my playing career."
Forest were bottom of the table when Pearce took over from Frank Clark just before Christmas and started brightly under him, winning five of their next seven games.
But they only won one of 14 league matches after that and their fate was sealed when they could only draw 1-1 at home with Wimbledon on Saturday.
They play their last match of the season on Sunday at Newcastle United.
